text: a judge sitting in Scotland's highest
civil court has rejected a request for
an injunction preventing the suspension
of Parliament but says it's in the
public interest for a full hearing as
soon as possible a group of 75
parliamentarians were seeking an interim
interdict similar to an injunction at
the Court of Session ahead of a full
hearing Lord Doherty said he believed
the full hearing should be moved forward
to next Tuesday or Wednesday well let's
go to our correspondent Laura Gordon
who's in Edinburgh for us so Lorna just
explain exactly what this means what the
significance of it is well in effect I
think we're in a holding pattern at the
moment the judge declined to grant that
emergency injunction he said he wants to
hear the full arguments set out they did
in the end settle on a date that full
hearing which was originally scheduled
for next Friday because of course the
moves to bring this case to court have
been in the offing for some time the
petitioner started this court action
back in July anticipating they said that
the government would seek to prorogue
parliament so the original discussions
were that it might be it was originally
set for Friday there was a little
discussions in there whether it it would
get moved forward to Tuesday or
Wednesday at the end of the hearing a
decision was made that it would in fact
take place next Tuesday the judge Lord
Doherty said it was in the interest of
justice and in the public interest that
it proceeds sooner rather than later he
said in declining the interim interdict
he said he was not satisfied that there
was a cogent need for an interim
interdict and he wouldn't decide whether
the petitioners have a prima facie case
until the full arguments are set out so
now we know that while it's a holding
pattern for now the full hearing will be
next Tuesday and the speediness of the
process thus far would suggest that he
would make a decision very very quickly
thereafter reaction has there been to
this
well putting this in a holding pattern
as he very well described it Laura yeah
we heard Johanna cherry the lead
petitioner came outside court of course
she is one of more than 70
parliamentarians and peers who have
joined this action at the Court of
Session she talked of the timetable she
talks also of the expenses I think we
can hear a little bit of her now the
judge has declined to grant interim
orders that's like an emergency order
but he hasn't made any ruling on the
merits of our argument the prorogation
should be stopped he wants to hear
further and full arguments on Tuesday
morning here at the Court of Session
before making decision and so I see that
as a victory for us he has said there's
no urgency over the weekend because of
course the order for the order that came
from Val Morel on wed and steve says
that parliament cannot be proved before
the 9th of September which is a week on
Monday but he's going to hear the full
arguments as to whether or not that
flora Gatien should proceed on Tuesday
of next week and he's fined the expenses
of this hearing to be expenses in the
cause which means that the ultimate
Victor and we'll get the expenses of it
well interestingly joanna cherry also
pointed out that she has given the court
a sworn affidavit talking about how she
believes there is not enough time for
Parliament to properly scrutinize what
is going on ahead of exit day we heard
the lawyer for the petitioners in court
invite the prime minister to hand in a
sworn affidavit as well that was
acknowledged acknowledged by the
government lawyer although not
necessarily accepted of course it's not
up to the petitioners whether or not the
Prime Minister submits a sworn affidavit
what we don't know at this point is
whether if he chooses not to whether
they might request that the judge
compels him to of course that will
ultimately be that in the judges gift
his decision whether or not he does it
but you know
yesterday in court it was said that this
case was unprecedented and I certainly
think from what happened here in that
short 20 minute or so hearing just a
short while ago you really did get the
feeling that we are really are in
uncharted territory when it comes to the
courts ok Lorna thank you very much for
that
Lorna Gordon in Edinburgh
